ground_truth: She stubs out the cigarette and takes down the guilt frame photo. Setting her chin defiantly, she shuts the black and white photo away in the drawer. In the morning, she's lying asleep on her bed fully clothed as Charlotte in a skull cap and dressing gown bursts into her room and starts pulling clothes from the wardrobe. Later, elegantly dressed on the porch, Charlotte tries to eavesdrop on Stuart and Skeeter as she waters her plants. He starts walking away. Skeeter, glancing back towards the house, frowns speculatively. She strides past her smiling date. In a diner, shirt sleeves rolled up, he's ordered oysters. They clink oyster and cracker. He reaches across and takes her hand. She responds with a smile. Outside the diner, Stuart grabs her hand. He steps towards her and kisses her on the lips. Mae Mobley is sitting on Aibileen's knee with a picture book. Hilly comes out of her house grimacing. She pushes aside a press photographer. Toilets are scattered on the yard. She cradles her Yard of the Month sign and carries it inside to the amusement of the onlookers. Mae Mobley, with her knickers down, proudly sits on one of the many toilets scattered across the lawn. Elizabeth drags her off. Tenderly carrying Mae Mobley in her arms, Aibileen sets her down on the lawn surrounded by a dozen toilets. She kneels in front of her. Taking hold of her hands, she looks deeply into the child's moon face. They hug each other. Elizabeth, watching coldly from the front door, goes inside. At the Phelan's, Skeeter, Josefo, and Pascagoula are watching civil rights activist Medgar Evers on TV. Charlotte turns off the TV. The servants scoot away. Charlotte grabs Skeeter by the hand. Skeeter pulls away and goes. On a bus on her way home, Aibileen is napping. Henry, sitting nearby, looks up from his book. The bus stops. The driver switches on the inside lights and faces the passengers. Aibileen and Henry, who have been sitting at the back of the bus, hurriedly get out and walk off down the dark street. He goes. Seeing Henry disappear around the corner, Aibileen starts to run. Civil rights activist Roy Wilkins comments. Aibileen trips and falls. Minnie's children leave the kitchen. The three younger ones pile into one bed. The two friends put their arms around each other. With a somber expression, Skeeter flips back to the front cover of the LIFE magazine, which shows the distraught widow comforting her young son. At the foot mansion, Minnie is hoovering down a stuffed standing grizzly bear on a corner dice. She looks towards the fad and steps down from the platform. She strolls through the spacious rooms and comes into the bedroom, making a beeline for the bathroom door.

Toilets are scattered on the yard, a comedic statement against her by neighborhood pranksters. She cradles her Yard of the Month sign, evidence of her prized gardening skills, and carries it inside to the amusement of the onlookers. Mae Mobley, with her knickers down, proudly sits on one of the many toilets scattered across the lawn, a naive participant in the spectacle. Elizabeth drags her off, embarrassed by the scene. Elizabeth, watching coldly from the front door, goes inside, upset about the tarnished social image. The driver switches on the inside lights and faces the passengers. Aibileen and Henry, who have been sitting at the back of the bus, hurriedly get out and walk off down the dark street, a path made familiar by their daily routine. He goes. Seeing Henry disappear around the corner, Aibileen starts to run, spurred by a sudden realization. Civil rights activist Roy Wilkins comments, his voice echoing in her mind as a source of inspiration. Aibileen trips and falls. Minnie's children leave the kitchen, having just finished their dinner. The three younger ones pile into one bed, a nightly ritual that brings them comfort. The two friends put their arms around each other, seeking solace in their shared experiences. With a somber expression, Skeeter flips back to the front cover of the LIFE magazine, which shows the distraught widow Coretta Scott King comforting her young son, a poignant image of loss and resilience. She saunters through the spacious corridors and enters the bedroom, making a beeline for the wardrobe door.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: She extinguishes the torch and picks up the guilt-ridden mirror painting. Setting her chin confidently, she hides the colorful painting inside the backpack. In the afternoon, she's snoozing on her carpet fully shod as Beatrice in a pirate hat and leather jacket storms into her cave and starts flinging books from the shelf. Eventually, casually clad on the balcony, Beatrice attempts to spy on Roger and Scooter as she mows her lawn. He begins skipping away. Scooter, peering back towards the barn, scowls thoughtfully. She dances past her grinning rival. In a bistro, jacket untucked, he's eaten clams. They clang bell and drumstick. He leans over and grabs her paw. She counters with a wink. Outside the bistro, Roger seizes her elbow. He leans away from her and pecks her on the nose. Baby Sue is perched on Zelda's shoulder with a coloring book. Billy emerges from his cabin grimacing. He shoves aside a police officer. Buckets are strewn on the grass. He embraces his Trophy of the Year plaque and transports it indoors to the delight of the onlookers. Baby Sue, with her fashion down, gleefully perches on one of the many buckets scattered across the meadow. Veronica yanks her off. Lovingly carrying Baby Sue in her grip, Zelda sets her down on the grass encircled by a dozen buckets. She squats before her. Gripping her paws, she gazes deeply into the child's solar face. They clutch each other. Veronica, observing distantly from the attic, retreats inside. At the Daffodil's, Scooter, Juan, and Rosetta are observing jazz performer Sammy Davis Jr. on radio. Beatrice powers down the radio. The dancers scurry away. Beatrice seizes Scooter by the elbow. Scooter jerks away and departs. On a train on her path back, Zelda is dreaming. Lester, situated nearby, looks up from his script. The train halts. The engineer switches on the interior candles and faces the travelers. Zelda and Lester, who have been reclining at the front of the train, hastily alight and trot down the dim avenue. He vanishes. Watching Lester vanish around the junction, Zelda starts to gallop. Activist Malcolm X speaks. Zelda stumbles and crumbles. Minnie's siblings exit the parlor. The trio of older ones huddle into one crate. The pair of colleagues wrap their limbs around each other. With a pensive look, Scooter flips forward to the back cover of the TIME anthology, which depicts the distraught spouse cradling her young sibling. At the base villa, Minnie is dusting up a plush standing polar bear on a corner dice. She eyes the breeze and steps up onto the podium. She wanders through the cramped hallways and enters the closet, making a zigzag for the closet shelf.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: She extinguishes the cigarette and hides the photo with determination. In the morning, fully dressed, she’s interrupted by Charlotte, who bursts in and rummages through the wardrobe. Later, Charlotte overhears Stuart and Skeeter during her porch gardening. At a diner, Stuart and Skeeter share a moment, holding hands and exchanging a kiss. Mae Mobley sits with Aibileen, while Hilly reacts to toilets scattered in her yard, amusing onlookers. Elizabeth coldly watches Aibileen tenderly care for Mae Mobley among the toilets. Meanwhile, Skeeter, Josefo, and Pascagoula watch Medgar Evers on TV before Charlotte turns it off. Skeeter pulls away and leaves. Aibileen naps on a bus ride home, gets off with Henry, and runs after he leaves. Roy Wilkins comments as Aibileen trips and falls. Minnie’s children settle into bed, and Minnie herself finishes cleaning, moving through the mansion towards the bathroom.
